Fall of Cybertron continues the story from War for Cybertron, and makes a number of welcome improvements to the gameplay. The most noticeable of these is that the makers of the game seemed to realize that what they were going for was more digital storytelling than real gameplay, so the mechanics of the game have been tweaked to support the narrative, which is even stronger than in the first game. The character development in this game is top notch, and the emotional aspect of the game is extremely compelling.\n\nIf you liked War for Cybertron, then this game is an auto-buy. Hands down. Even if you didn't, this game is worth looking into. This game is far more playable and enjoyable in my opinion.
Could a transformers game ever be good or decent? Yes this is proof, For the hardcore fans only though\n8.5/10
Worth playing for the epic final level alone. Surprisingly good.
This game is amazing. whal the game has a few gliches, they are intertaning. the wepons evan feal like wepons. 9.5/10

Like the previous Transformers game by High Moon Studios, Fall of Cybertron is lovingly crafted by fans of Transformers for fans of Transformers.  The average/slightlly-above-average gameplay is nicely complemented with references to the G1 series and movie, making even the tedious gameplay bits (Cliffjumper and Grimlock) bring a smile to my face.  I did not try the multiplayer as it is my understanding the servers are rife with cheaters and likely not worth the time.  That's okay, the single player is strong enough to warrent the price whenever this game is on sale.\n\nIf you grew up with the G1 toys and want to relive some of the childhood battles that only existed in your mind then you need to play Fall of Cybertron and it's weaker-but-memorable prequel; War for Cybertron.
lohnt sich\n

I love this game. If you're a Transformers fan, it's a must have. Also, comparing this game to it's prequel (War for Cybertron), the controls in this game are so much smoother, gameplay is better, story is awesome and pretty much accurate, and the multiplayer is fun. Definitely a great game!

Transformers or not, this game is a whole lot of fun to play; the variety of characters changes the gameplay every other level, it's not too easy, lot of weapons, etc. Only problem is the SP campaign is kinda short and the MP is somewhat tacked on, so only get this on sale.

A great sequel, and great game in general. Strong presentation for both new fans, and old school fans. Everything about this game is just written in fan service and it is all excellent! The only downside is that I can't really recommend this game to a non Transformers fan, seeing as how much of the story and references can only be noticed by those who have been around the series for a while. The gameplay while fun may not appeal to a non fan. Although if you want to give it a shot, start from the begining with War for Cybertron,. It's a great game also and is sure to hook you in :D

Of all the recent Transformers games, this one is the best.  Every character you play has something that makes them unique, something the other games lacked.  While it is linear gameplay, at least it doesn't feel like a rail shooter.  Gimlock is where this game really shines.  Playing the great Dinobot is just too fun!  While it doesn't do everything I would like to see in a Transformers game, what it does is polished and perfected.
omg i loved this game

The first game of this series was the first game that I ever played for my PS3, and I loved it. Low and behold this game has reignited my love for Decepticons, skrew the autobots. This game is a god damn masterpiece and all I have played so far is the multiplayer it is going to have me hooked just like the first game did. If you are worrying that they didn't improve anything, don't everything runs as smooth as butter, the gameplay is a mix of Twisted Metal, old school Quake speed and jumps, and Battlefield/Team Fortress classes and teamwork, four of my favorite franchises all in one. Get this and you will have a hell of a time I promise you, we need more people for multiplayer and Escalation anyway, so if you do get it and want to play hit me up with a friend request.\n\nI absolutly love everything about this game so far, I have not tried single player yet, so from that I give this game a 8.75 out of 10, just for multiplayer. DECEPTICONS FOREVER!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
Awsome game for Transformers fans.\nYou can see it was made by people who love Transformers

Fall of Cybertron continues the story from War for Cybertron, and makes a number of welcome improvements to the gameplay. The most noticeable of these is that the makers of the game seemed to realize that what they were going for was more digital storytelling than real gameplay, so the mechanics of the game have been tweaked to support the narrative, which is even stronger than in the first game. The character development in this game is top notch, and the emotional aspect of the game is extremely compelling.\n\nIf you liked War for Cybertron, then this game is an auto-buy. Hands down. Even if you didn't, this game is worth looking into. This game is far more playable and enjoyable in my opinion.

Like the previous Transformers game by High Moon Studios, Fall of Cybertron is lovingly crafted by fans of Transformers for fans of Transformers.  The average/slightlly-above-average gameplay is nicely complemented with references to the G1 series and movie, making even the tedious gameplay bits (Cliffjumper and Grimlock) bring a smile to my face.  I did not try the multiplayer as it is my understanding the servers are rife with cheaters and likely not worth the time.  That's okay, the single player is strong enough to warrent the price whenever this game is on sale.\n\nIf you grew up with the G1 toys and want to relive some of the childhood battles that only existed in your mind then you need to play Fall of Cybertron and it's weaker-but-memorable prequel; War for Cybertron.

Достойное продолжение мощного TPS по вселенной Трансформеров. Картинка похорошела, многие пейзажи заслуживают того чтобы красоваться на вашем рабочем столе. Линейность никто не отменял, но локации стали просторнее, вы узрите последние дни разрушающегося Кибертрона во всей красе, поучаствуете в спасении(и разрушении) Ковчега автоботов. Если в прошлой части вам удалось вкусить лишь более-менее одинаковых персонажей(3 вида наземных и один воздушный), то здесь к вашим услугам большая часть ключевых персонажей, включая гештальта Грубикуса, крушить металл которым - сплошное удовольствие. Совместное прохождение теперь только в виде эскалации, выживаем против нескольких волн управляемых ИИ ботов. Сетевые побоища, увы, не приносят удовлетворения, потому что на увеличившейся в разы карте зачастую вас ожидают только пара кемперов.

Cons:

- Still pricey for a pretty old game

Overall I'll recommend it. Buy it during steam sales.

reviewerDisplayName: add me on FB @ Dakota Lukasik
reviewText:
Transformers: Fall of Cybertron is an absolute delight for any fan of the series before boom boom Michael Bay era.
The classic design of the characters and areas really brings back a pleasant feeling of nostalgia, and the ability to transform from humanoid form to vehicular form at any given moment is a definite plus.
Though despite the aesthetic appeal of this game, the combat seems to be a bit repetitive, aside from the boss fights of course. The story is magnificent and immersive, though the dialogue, as expected, is pretty awful.
I would recommend buying this is you are a fan of the series.

So... I just started playing this game today, and I'm amazed by how intriguing it is. Most shooters take a while to lay out the plotline and introduce the characters, but with this game the action starts immediately. I start up the game and immediately there are decepticons pounding on the door and explosions to my left and right. PEW-PEW! From the very first chapter this game really latches on to the player. The graphics are amazing throughout the cut scenes and the battle scenes.

There are barely any glitches or bugs with this game and everything runs smoothely. I'm extremely happy with the loading scenes since they barely take any times. Most games have a long loading screen as the battlefield and map gets loaded up, but with Transformers it's nearly instant. I'll be waiting for a door to open as the game loads less than 5 seconds and the door opens and I'm jumping right into the action.

I did have a little pet peeve with the driving mode within this game. Obviously, being Transformers, the way that the robots transform between modes is amazing graphically. The cars" look so damn cool

Transformers: Fall of Cybertron is leaps and bounds above the previous game. War for Crybertron wasn't a bad game, but it did feel like it was missing some sort of umph. FoC has so much more soul, the controls are tighter, the transformations feel smoother, and so much more. While the co-op option was removed, they used that extra time and energy to make the single player campaign so much better.

Much of the game is a prequel to events in the original series, and some of it will not be canon. However, the play on some events does not detract from the game at all. The constant homages to the Generation 1 series of cartoons as well as the movie add so much life to the game.

Overall, the game was constantly action packed, the Transformers you play are different enough to keep the play styler varied, the weapons were good, and the levels had a much better design this time around. To anyone who loves the Transformers, especially the original series, this is the game for you. For those who are looking for another action game, it still holds up, but it may not be as satisfying to non-fans. Solid game, solid fun, solid buy,

Fall of Cybertron picks up where War for Cybertron left off: Optimus Prime has commissioned an Ark to leave Cybertron behind to the Decepticons, a plan that some of his fellow 'bots question. Meanwhile, the Decepticons continue their conquest of the planet, and are hellbent on not allowing the Autobots to take the pacifistic route out of their conflict.

If you played War for Cybertron, you know what to expect from the singleplayer campaign: a solid Transformers story told during the early stages of the war, as viewed from both Autobot and Decepticon perspectives. Unlike War for Cybertron, in Fall you do not pick which faction's story you want to play through: instead, the story jumps from character-to-character, Autobot to Decepticon, depending on the narrative. This was neither a pro nor a con: the story is still tight, and although the 'choice' was removed, you likely ended up playing both factions' storylines in WfC anyway.

The different bots in FoC all have unique abilities beyond just their alt modes: Jazz, for example, has a grappling hook that allows him to traverse vertically throughout his level. Playing as Cliffjumper switches up the usual run-and-gun in this game for more stealth-oriented gameplay, sneaking up on enemies and dispatching them with quick executions. But the coolest ability is as you play through the Combaticons' story parts, eventually merging into the rampaging Bruticus. Playing as a combiner is awesome.

Once you've completed the singleplayer mode, you'll want to jump into the multiplayer. Here's where the game really shines--but also exposes some of its biggest flaws. The actual meat of the multiplayer is great: customizing your bots is hands down the coolest thing in this game, creating your own builds, color schemes, unlocking new parts, and ranking up to gain new weaponry and abilities will consume your time. The gameplay is frenetic, and shooting other Transformers never gets old. There are a lot of Hell yeah!" moments to be had while playing this game.

That being said

As someone who somewhat enjoyed its predecessor, I can say once more that I have enjoyed High Moon's recent Transformers game.

Upon starting the game you are right away immersed in the civil war between the brutish Decepticons and the noble Autobots while witnessing the full spectacle of Cybertrons war-torn atmosphere. After a brief tutorial level that tries its best not to be, you start on the very linear campaign that kind of pulls you in the direction you have to go in whilst it is definitely entertaining there isn't really any room for tactics.

The A.I. (although technically all transformers are A.I. anyways) can be easily picked off in some scenarios; however, in other scenarios they actually work together to flank you and rush you. I was playing on the hard difficulty and I actually died a couple times because of this. Turns out even Optimus Prime can have a hard time with infantry grunts weilding shotguns. The bigger more eviler Decepticon grunts are actually kind of a challenge to kill (again on hard I haven't tried easy) especially when there is two or more. This game does a decent job at giving you enemies to fight.

Another thing I didn't like was that exploring often left you unrewarded. There were plenty of places that looked like it would bare loot but it did not or it was just one of these audio log things. The audio logs are somewhat interesting as it provides some story filler and insight to Transformers lore but are very easy to find.

My last problem with the game is it runs at 60 FPS max (I have a 120hz monitor) and I've never really been a fan of Unreal Engine 3. The control customization is like how you can change a button layout in a console version of the game; the entire game kind of feels a bit too much like a console port but it's not that bad at least.

Still these minor nuisances did not keep me from enjoying the campaign there are plenty of climactic moments and fun weapons to use to wreak havok with. The actual Transforming tactic can be pretty useful but you will have to figure out yourself how to use it.

To conclude, this game is I'd have to assign a value of 20-30 dollars depening on how much you enjoy the multiplayer. It's a good experience but does not offer much replayability but if you are a Transformers fan then this game is a must.

Has a better story than the Michael Bay movies if you can belive that. Regardless, decent 3rd person action game. You rotate between Tranformers and Decepticons giving you access to both stories. Узрите силу истинного вампира  глаза блюдца ^^

Growing up on Transformers this game-franchise comes closest to realizing my childhood fantasies of being able to be/play a Transformer. The game has a great storyline, awesome multiplayer and very good art direction. That being said, there is something terribly wrong with this game.

First and foremost, this game seems to be all about the money, not about community and/or support of said community. Fall of Cybertron is a typical release from one of the biggest companies in gaming history. As such the price for the core game is kept artificially high (even during sales) and the DLC is overpriced and lacklustre.
The development team was taken off the game about a month or two after release so patching bugs or changing detrimental flaws is just not going to happen.

The game is a straight up console port with no PC love given whatsoever. The only reason it isn't dead yet is its community. People that want to play Transformers and are willing to put up with the non-existant support and consequentially the rampant and blatant cheaters that plague the multiplayer landscape.

It's sad that a game and a franchise that has such devout following gets so little love from its own creators. Personally I hope that one day a company that cares about the franchise (beyond seeing it as a big golden cash-cow) can have a go at making a great Transformers game. One that has some lasting vision, and some heart. For now, fans of the franchise are stuck with this: an awesome game that could have been so much more were it not for corporate greed and the ever present God-money.

Can I recommend this game? Yes. But only if you, like me, are a devout follower of the franchise. At full price, even a year after release, with the dwindeling player numbers and the non-existant support, it is just not going to be worth it for the average gamer. It is a real shame that something so awesome can leave such a bad taste in your mouth.
Roll out

Being a fan of the show and the movies since when I was a kid, I got this game from GAMESTOP Online store as it was at half price and just kinda wanted to test out something new. Bright and visually stunning, with an incredible animation as you morph from bot form to vehicle form every now and then, it does satisfy your tastebuds if you really want to go for some Transformers action. Having said this, the gameplay however is incredibly mundane. Storyline was stale and not really alluring, hence for all the work and credit that went into making it so stunning, the pros were quickly neutralized by the cons in the game.

I thought I was gonna buy a fan-oriented game, but I was wrong: it's a very, very good TPS enjoyable by fans and newcomers. The characters are very much as they were intended to behave (not like in the recent movies...) The variety of gameplay in this campaign is remarkable, plus it has a nice multiplayer mode and the classic escalation cooperative mode...don't miss it, you'd lose a very good game
Don't listen to the reviewers. This game is the ♥♥♥♥!
The climactic battle scene was one of the greatest experiences of recent video game memory. Worth trudging through the slow parts to get to it.

Actually enjoyed this one more than I thought due to the mediocrity of the previous 'War for Cybertron'. The campaign is more interesting introducing and controlling familiar characters that are a mix of the movie and G1 versions. The campaign also kept things interesting as one mission is stealth oriented while another is focused on running through a lab looking for lost team mates. The story also bounces between Autobot and Decepticon or different characters, unlike the previous games here's one side, now here's the other. It greatly adds to the story and makes it less rigid.\nI briefly played the multiplayer which feels like a lesser version of COD style level progression unlocking weapons and add-ons but the reward to level ratio is skewed. It feels like they're on to something, if only they put more into it.
it is rare to see a transformer game succede but this goes beyond amazing ITS HELLA EPIC\n\nWolf rating 10/10

What a spectacular game. If you are a fan of transformers in general and specially if u liked the first one (transformers - war for cybertron) u are gonna LOVE this one. the campaign is not that long (beat it in 2-3 days) but it more than makes up for it with the magnificent graphics, playabable characters and intense action. You will switch between autobot and decepticon perspective more than in the first game.
Not to spoil anything but the last chapter.... just wow. Definitely going into one of my top video game fights of ALL TIME.

Strongly recommend this game. At full or sale price, this is a MUST HAVE for any transformers fan.

Campaign was great.  It switched up between heroes consistantly and at a pace that made sure you weren't sick of them but actually wanted to play more of them when the levels were over.  The last level was perfect, with epic battles that kept you entertained while the cut scenes actually felt important to the story.  Multiplayer is exciting and the controls are good.  Do not know about balances yet but each team has access to the same units so team wise it is balanced.\n\nFor the Transformers fans out there the game is worth playing just for the 1986 Transformers movie references.
You can play as dinosaur and command transforming city, thumbs up!

Very fun game. Awesome voice acting and storyline. Though as awesome as this game may be, I feel that the it's predecessor was a better game given that every mission was a party of three, giving you a joice to pick among the three. That's not to say that I didn't enjoy playing solo at all its just some parts of the game I'd rather be in a group (more dialogue this way). Maybe in the next installation it will be a mixture of solo and group to diversify the game play even more than what it already is.
Another complaint (though this will change in later date) is the price tag at the moment. Game retails at $59.99 which I don't think the game is worth that much.

Bottom line: I do recommend this game and you will have a ton of fun playing, but try to catch it on sale like I did. Believe I got this for $15 which is absolutely worth it.

However, this game is not worth the 59.99 price tag that looms over it. The best a prson can do is wait for a Steam sale or if there is an Activision sale, like the recent one.

I've always been somewhat of a small time Transformers fan. Although I never watched the original G1 Cartoons or Beast Wars, I did watch Armada and some of Energon, as well as the Bayformers trilogy. Back in 2008 I bought Transformers: War for Cybertron and I loved it. I never got to buying Fall of Cybertron until now when the Activison Steam Sale came up and I was not dissapointed.

The story for Fall of Cybertron in my opinion is much better compared to War for Cybertron's. The humor is still there and the characters have their own sense of personality, which I like. Unlike War for Cybertron, there aren't two other characters supporting you through the mission, which also means that the co-op campaign from the first game is not present aswell. However, you have an ingame store in which you can buy and upgrade weapons. items and perks using Energon. The gameplay is overall similar to the first game and it felt natural to me. Besides the story, I have yet to try the multiplayer, or Escalation, which was one of my favorite parts of War for Cybertron.

Overall, Fall of Cybertron is much better than it's predecessor and I enjoyed it very much. The only negative thing I can think of besides no co-op campaign is that the game is still priced $59.99. If you wait for a Steam Sale however, this should not be a problem.

Let me say this first - I am no multiplayer kinda guy. This game without that, with the story, the action, and all the different characters is still incredible! There is a great deal of weapons and upgrades, so you can stick with making one gun really powerful or just generally enhance all of them. The fact you can swap your weapon hand in this game, as apposed to the last lends itself to the really fun gunplay in which you either have to take cover or keep moving and dodging. Most the cover is destructible in some way by the way. The transforming into a vehicle has great animation and it just feels fantastic every time I do it in game whether in combat or to move around. Also, I should mention each character feels unique in their own way, and you can sense the love that went into this game, it even has a few fanservice moments if you watched the old show. I'm currently playing it my second time with keyboard and still feels pretty good. Overall, this is one mind-blowing game with some major HELL YEAH!" moments. If you pick it up

I won't spoil or try not to spoil parts of the game with my personal review of Transformers: Fall for Cybertron or TFC for short. I played the game on Normal difficulty and finished it in around 10 hours maybe less.

Story-
I won't say much about the story here, its best for you to experience it yourself, but its nothing to write home about. You will understand exactly what needs to be done and whats going on. There are references to other Transformer things which was done very well.

Graphics-
The graphics are well thought out and the overall design of things is amazing. A mix of metal and organic terrain made for great level design in terms of where you went and how you moved. I can't say the same for graphics.... The graphics are poor when up close and worse when you're in a cutscene. The teaser videos for the game looked so awesome, but thats where the shiny-ness" ends. Your character looks great and so do other bots. I enjoy the little things that shift and move on your character. Transformations are also fun to watch. I liked Vortex and Jazz for their transformations.


UI-

I'm sure it would have been tolerable for console but not by much. Repeatedly having to press the cycle page button to go to each tab was a pain in the neck. Why not click on the tab that we wanted to be in? Again

Fall of Cybertron is a prime example and perhaps one of the best examples of a licenced game done well. Everything in it from the environments, to the lore, to the characters and voice actors all magnificently capture the essense and feel that makes Transformers Transformers. In remembrance to my War for Cybertron review, I shall now list 30 things off the top of my head that makes Transformers Fall of Cybertron a great game:

1. It's got friggin' Transformers
2. You get to play as all the iconic and memorable characters from the franchise
3. All of the controls have been streamlined and refined in transition from the last game making for a fantastic gaming experience
4. Varied and extremely well paced levels based on which Transformer you play as meaning you will never get bored as you play!
5. You get to be complete badasses as all of the guys you play as but even more so as BRUTICUS AND GRIMLOCK
6. Peter Cullen reprises his role as Optimus Prime in addition to the remaining extremely talented cast who played all of their parts to perfection. The voice acting in this game truly is some of the best in the medium.
7. True to form and true to name. Everything in the game is what one would expect of a Transformers Cybertron game and even more.
8. A gripping narrative that explores the last dying hours of Cybertron; a tale truly remarkable, one of civil war, struggle, freedom, camaraderie, loss and hope.
9. Well rounded, extremely likeable, very memorable, nostalgia-inducing cast of characters that will make you love the franchise even if you have never watched or played a single Transformers show or game.
10. Wonderfully crafted environments that really make you feel that you are in a dying planet ravaged by centuries of warfare.
11. Incredible character models and animations that make transformations so seemless, robot movements so natural and moving, transforming environments that really make you feel that you are in a living, breathing world.
12. Everything that made the first game (sans Co-op) made it to the sequel... BUT WITH MORE! You can now sprint, dodge, and air dash!
13. All of the new additions above made playing as the Transformers feel like you're actually playing as trained warriors as opposed to simply walking behemoths with big guns... Now, you can be a walking behemoth with big guns AND ALSO BE MORE BADASS BY USING BADASS EVASIVE MANEUVERS!
14. The game does a fantastic introduction wherein you actually play in the final chapter and then the next chapters have you revisiting events that happened before that final chapter in order for you to find out about all of the things that lead to said finale. In other words, the game throws you into THE most intense moments of the narrative as the INTRODUCTION, and IT WAS FANTASTIC.
15. One may think that because they showed you the most intense moments in the first chapter since the first chapter is also the final chapter, the rest of the game wouldn't be as exciting... WRONG! This game is filled with what can be coined as ♥♥♥♥ yeah!" moments wherein there are these moments that are so damn epic that you just can't help and clench your fist and position your arms into a victorious pose all while saying
date: whispering or even screaming "♥♥♥♥ Yeah!". And this game
recommended: is FILLED with it.\n16. The actual final chapter
voteText: is EVEN MORE INTENSE than when you first experienced it. It is absolutely MINDBLOWING.\n17. Remember how I talked about those "♥♥♥♥ Yeah!" moments? Grimlock's Transformation
helpfulPercent: that is all.\n18. You know what
votesHelpful: I lied. Here's another: Friggin' Metroplex\n19. Incredible dialogue

reviewText:
Fall of Cybertron continues the storyline from the previous game, War for Cybertron. In a way, it did some things I wasn't too terribly thrilled about, but did others that kind of made up for it. WfC had a neat campaign, in which you got to play as the Decepticons and the Autobots and see each side of the respective storylines. FoC, on the other hand, mixes it up and does it more in a sort of episodic formula. On one hand, this is a pretty neat approach to the game, and it allows you to try out the various mechanics the games offers. However, I can't help but think it's an overglorified tutorial for what is apparently supposed to the main part of this game, the multiplayer. And while I enjoy multiplayer games every once in a while, this isn't really the sort of game I'd play an online portion for.

The big hook of this game, for me, was the dinobots. Especially Grimlock, since they advertised him in many of the trailers. The problem, of course, is that you get to play him, but only for one mission. And it's near the end of the game. However, playing as Grimlock is just insanely and wonderfully satisfying. You're playing a big badass transforming-robot-TRex and the game just makes you feel like almsot nothing can seriously harm you. And best of all, he's one of the good guys. Unfortunately, if you want to play as him online, you have to buy a separate pack that contains all four of the dinobots. Or rather, 4 playable dinobots.

Overall, the changes made to Fall of Cybertron don't necessarily hinder it, but if you're someone looking for a decent single player experience, I would recommend sticking with the predecessor. However, if you can bare it for about 11 chapters, you'll be rewarded with one of the most satisfying experiences I've played in a while.

reviewText: The best transformers game!

Definitely the best Transformers game ever made. The whole thing is a love letter to guys who grew up with the franchise and you can tell that the team behind it really wanted to do the property justice. They delivered in a big way.

Fall of Cybertron is a third-person shooter with surprisingly tight gameplay, a phenomenal campaign, good competitive multiplayer, and a co-op horde mode.

The campaign is split down the middle. Half of the levels have you playing as the Autobots, through their side of the story. And the other is the Decepticons, playing through their side. Both parts of the campaign are brilliantly done and there's a lot to love if you're a Transformers nerd. Optimus Prime running through the trenches screaming needlessly about freedom brings a smile to my face every time. Over the course of the campaign, you'll play as many different characters with unique abilities, and each has their own feel. It's a great feature that makes every level feel different from the last. It's a great little campaign that never gets boring. This is the main attraction of the game, for sure.

Throughout the levels are stations where you can select your loadout and upgrade your weapon with resources you gather as you kill enemies and play through the game. These upgrades go across both factions and all characters, and there's a lot of options. Weapon variety is great, and it's made even better because it ties into the upgrade system. Most upgrades are simple (upgrade a gun's accuracy, or its ammo capacity, etc.) but if you buy all the upgrades for a given weapon, you get a more unique and powerful upgrade that varies from weapon to weapon. These upgrades stay unlocked even when you replay the game, so it's functionally a constant new game+ mode where you can continue to play through and unlock upgrades. Great for replay value.

The gameplay is absolutely perfect for what a Transformers game should be. At any time you can switch into vehicle mode to increase mobility or access a different set of weapons, and it's actually balanced very well. Sure you may already be a giant death robot, but if you transform into a giant death tank you have access to heavier, long range weapons, at the cost of speed. Or maybe transform into a fast car that has no real firepower to speak of, but insane speed. It's all very smooth and functions well. All depends on the character/class you're playing as.

Multiplayer can be played in a cooperative horde mode/tower defense style, or traditional competitive play. There's not much to say about the horde mode. It's the same horde/tower defense mode we've seen dozens of times, and you collect resources to unlock new parts of the map, weapons, etc. like in Nazi Zombies. It's fun, but nothing to write home about.

The competitive mode lets you fully customize your own Transformer (you can have presets from both factions) using bits from existing characters (as well as full control over the paint job), and it's a lot of fun. You're simply pitted against other players in traditional MP modes (deathmatch, domination, etc.). It's balanced and works well. No complaints whatsoever. It's a fun mode that is surprisingly well-balanced.

One thing to note is that, strangely, the PC port does NOT have controller support in some menus. It does for most of the game, but some menus it's just absent with no explanation. For instance, the upgrade system I mentioned earlier? The upgrade menu requires you to use your mouse and keyboard, even if you've been playing the game with a controller. A minor inconvenience, but an inconvenience nonetheless.

We'll probably never see another Transformers game like this, because the sequel was tied into the Michael Bay movie series because of corporate meddling, and passed off to another developer.

Big time recommendation by the Transformers fanboy in me who grew up.
Amazing game, it brought back my love for tranformers long before I even played it! I just hope more people get the game and have the same experience I did (and still do)

This game continues to be a great game. I've played through the single player campaign so many times since 2012 and it still remains one of my most cherished games in my steam library. The single player story plays out smoothly but at a pace that doesn't leave you getting too bored, the enemies are challenging ( and yes, can sometimes be difficult ), but the story told as you progress is worth it.

Multiplayer is a great experience, though 3 years after the game has been released the servers aren't as alive as they used to be. Escalation is also fun, with a team of like-minded robots taking on waves and waves of Decepticons.

In my opinion, -this- was the last great Transformers game. This is where this franchise ends, not with Rise of the Dark Spark. Avoid that game like the plague.

reviewText: I am not and never have been a fan of anything Transformers, but Fall of Cybertron is a blast beginning to end.

After finishing Transformers™: War for Cybertron I jumped right into Fall of Cybertron, while i was just as impressed and eger to carry on with the story and action, at first the control change ♥♥♥♥♥♥ me off a little and this is probably the only bad thing i can say about the game, well that and it did seem a bit shorter than the first. You see some new faces in Fall of Cybertron and even a new introduction to the Dinobots which i have to say i really enjoyed. Top marks for both games.

I simply want to extend my thanks to this studio for this phenomenal game! Not only were the visuals and sound effects impressive, but the playful banter between characters, music, story, and everything was incredible. Being able to play through all my beloved Transformers characters brought me back to my childhood and being able to crush my enemies in epic battles as Cybertron crumbled around me was something I've wished for for so long. The same goes for War for Cybertron. While the story seems to have finished, I look forward to future titles whether they are in the Transformers universe or elsewhere. Truly outstanding work that painted a clear, creative picture of how Cyberton fell while still adhering to the classic feel and overall story of the original series. Awesome!

I love Transformers. I also love third person shooters. As it turns out, the two can go great together given a proper developer. High Moon demonstrated that you can make a good liscensed game once with War for Cybertron, and have done so again in this sequel. Though it lacks a coop campaign and STILL bafflingly lacks configurable controls and any kind of in-game chat, the available control loadouts are solid and the campaign as before is excellent, showing the last days of the war in brutal detail with a multitude of playable characters, devastating weapons and tight dialogue. It retains a cooperative horde mode and competitive multiplayer, and these offerings have also been improved. Several features have been added and retooled- you can now sprint and switch the camera from your right to left shoulder at will.  Fall of Cybertron may not be the game of the year, but it is the definitive Transformers game.

reviewText:
A really terrific 3rd-person shooter and a role model for all Transformers games.

PROS:
+Great story
+Nice graphics
+Awesome transforming details
+Transform almost anytime
+Great vehicle modes
+Generally terrific voice acting
+Classic Transformers script
+Character creation in multiplayer

CONS:
-Short campaign
-No singleplayer other than campaign
-Multiplayer is infested with hackers
-Boring Bruticus/Grimlock play
-Occasional missing effects
-Weapons are either underpowered or overpowered (in most cases)
-Overpriced
-Poorly ported to PC (No custom controls, etc.)

My advice: Get it on sale, play the campaign through on all 3 difficulties, and play multiplayer on private servers with friends. Thanks for reading.

reviewText:
Picking off exactly where War for Cybertron left off, FoC is a direct continuation of the previous title with more of the same. The new additions are sparse: a store terminal for upgrades (welcomed addition); audio logs scattered throughout maps that don't add much; a couple of new autobots to play as, and...that's about it. This isn't criticism, it's observation.

Co-op's been taken out, which sucks (unless you never played the mode). I loved the banter that came from the co-op mode, and this takes away from the experience. You also don't get the 'episode recaps' from the previous title, instead the game directly continues onto the next chapter. A minor ommission, but still noticeable.

With that said, the game is overall a better experience than the previous title. It's still more of the same, but it's done better and on a grander scale. Rather than the linear maps of WfC, you get plenty of open fields with cover and weaponry strewn about. It's somewhat wasted on the Autobot section of the game, since they all transform into cars and the only objective is to run from A to B (yawn). But the Decepticon portion has you turning into a helicopter, and even the portions where you're an automobile are better since you're fighting under a large tanker with the objective of eliminating enemies rather than running through a very weak obstacle course.

There is a decent portion in the Autobot campaign where you play around with a grappling hook in a large, open area. But it's more of the exception rather than the rule, and even in that campaign it's still 90% linear with only one section letting you grapple freely in a large area. By far the Decepticon campaign is better, but I'll give the Autobot section some credit for trying some new things in the series.

The story is...meh. These are the last hours of Cybertron and there's not much to add other than 'we need to get the fu*k out of here'. But who plays these games for the story.

Not much more to say: if you liked the previous title you'll love this one. It's marginally better, which is to say it's a good experience+1.

reviewText:
Trasnformers Fall Of Cybertron is a great game for players of Transformers: War for Cyberton and new players to these great transformers games.
*For War For Cybertron players: Fall of cybertron brings new features such as the Teleraan I store to the game. Many of these changes are good, while others may annoy players of the prequel.
PROS:
Better Graphics overall
More weapon choices
More diverse looking enemies
More characters
More players overall in multiplayer
Better Story arc
CONS:
Cannot choose character in a mission: There is one way through each mission with one character and one possible outcome that you cannot change.
Not forced to try new weapons in campaign due to the Teletraan I store letting you access any gun you want nearly anywhere.
Very few Escalation players
Escalation is less of a different new experience each time. there are one or two good holdout positions to survive waves, whereas WfC had many interesting spots to hide, snipe or just straight out fight.
Guns look a lot more stubby and less like real life weapons and most lose all resemblence to Earth modern day weaponry.
There is a lot of pushing the button E over and over in cutscene parts, which is completely pointless as all if does is continue the cutscene.
Grenades are overall replaced by lame equipment that generally needs to be purchased.

*For New players or just regular TFC fans:
PROS:
Fun team survival mode (4 player)
good multiplayer with a prestige/infamy/reputation type of leveling system
very fun story arc that is necissary to understand the story behind Transformers Prime.
cool graphics
amazing metal world

CONS:
Not many survival (escalation) players
not many multiplayer modes are playable due to lack of players (only deathmatch availbible usually)
can't pick character for campaign (story)

reviewText:
Generic on-rails third person shooter. There are some very basic RPG mechanics but they are only there so you can buy DLC from the in game shop - yes really, please don't. Often I wondered why you have guns at all because there are endless respawns of stupid enemy AI until you pass the checkpoints. I didn't like the controls and gamepads aren't fully integrated (eg. you need to switch to your mouse if you want exit the shop).

I can't tell if the story is confusing or just random because I started ignoring it. The game is also littered with awful NPC dialogue which I suspect was stolen from an unknown trashy WW2 game. Every cliche you can think of has been abused.

Yet awesome explosions and it's Transformers! Yeah! Get this only if on sale, please don't buy DLC because it is offensive at how bad it is. The game isn't awful, it is exceptionally ok"."

reviewText:
a truly amazing game diving deep into the lore and history of the war between the autobots and the decepticons
it doesnt just tell you what happened on cybertron in the last six days of the plannet but it lets you control it, as you play you'll notice that youre not only playing as the autobots but also the decepticons, it has a good stealth portion of the game to keep your eyes peeled but also plenty of arena's were you fight off barage's of either Autobots or Decepticons (depending on who your fighting for) the only down side to this is the fact that you dont choose when you play as Autobot or Decepticon wich can make the player feel as though he or she has no choice in wether they massacre hundreds of little autobots with Bruticus's propeler shield or to trample purple piles of scrap whilst playing as grimlock.though the single player is the main course (to be expected) the multiplayer is riveting as you can choose from four customisable classes such as; Infiltrator (a small car-like vehicle with starter weapons the path blaster and the subsonic repeater but he also comes with the ability to cloak to ide from enemies), the scientist (a large jet-like vehicle with weapons such as the neutron assult rifle and the sub-orbital pistol and not to mention the ability to heal other team mates), the titan with a transformation similar to a tank the default weapons being the energon harvester and the X18 scrap-maker and the ability to turn his waste endlesly flinging his meele sword into any oncoming enemy and finnaly the destroyer a bit with a vehicular form simmilar to a van truck or heavy car depending on your choice of chasis with default weapons like the riot cannon and the A-4 Pulsar cannon you can make some pretty big boom's on your path to victory" he also has the abiltiy to drop a temporary shield with wich only the shots fired from your team can pass through this can aid your team when they reach a chocke point in the match

the multiplayer also has several modes wich are all self explanitory such as;

Team Death-Match
where your team has to kill 40 players from the enemy team to win

Conquest
where your team has to control nodes in order to gain points
date:
acquire 400 points to win the more nodes you have the faster you get points

capture the flag
obtain the flag and bring it to your teams base three times to win

head hunter
kill enemies so that they drop "sparks" (similar to CoD's dogtags) and collect 30 to win the match


the multiplayer flows almost effortlessly although this will depend on your internet speed
recommended:
computer capabilities and where the server is hosted from.

"if your in australia and your connected to a server in pakistan your gonna have a bad time"
Southpark Ski coach
2014"

reviewText: War for Cybertron was a suprise win for the franchise, and for franchise games everywhere. Fall of Cybertron returns with more of the relentless action, faithful characterisations and mind-blowing locations that made the first so popular.\n\nUnlike the first game, which contained 2 separate campaigns for Autobots and Decepticons, Fall of Cybertron switches you between both sides as you progress along the same storyline. Combat is intense and surprisingly challenging, and the addition of partially-destructable environments adds a tactical element to the fight. The voice-over work is great, with everything from the central characters to the incidental dialogue remaining faithful to the nature of each faction. The graphics are quite good, with a few trademarks of the Unreal engine unmistakably apparent - sometimes a positive, sometimes a negative. Glitches aren't frequent, thankfully, but the two or three I noticed required a re-load to get around. 8/10 - worth the 50 bucks.

reviewText:
Time Bought: Pre Ordered
Money Spent: $60
Worth The Price?: No (only because the mp is full of hackers and covert hackers, no support)
Position In Game At Time Of Review: Finished single player multiple times, Prime 100 (maxed out all classes in mp)


OMFG WHAT A GAME!!!!  The single player is pure EPICNESS!!!  You can really tell the developers put much thought and effort into making it!!!  It combines elements from such games as Tenchu, God of War, Gears of War, and many others!  The dramatic and saddened stories exhibited in the various character switches is GREAT.  You see SO many of the Transformers from almost every series created.  And it combines tv series, movies, and comic prologues very nice and neatly.  The sp has great replay value!  The multiplayer had a VERY bad launch but is now very intense and fun filled.  It will provide you with much gameplay for a long time.  There's actually not enough words of praise I can say enough for this WONDERFUL WORK!!!!!

Rating: 9/10

reviewText:
There has been many bad Transformers games lately basicly profiting off of the franchises name and the movies, but amongst them is a diamond, and this is that diamond.

This transformers game more represents the 80's transformers (the good days) and not the movie interpretation.

Overall:  9/10  The ending is a little anticlimactic but the game never has a dull moment, quality all the way through.

reviewText: A worthy sequel to the great War for Cybertron (and is not recommended without playing that first), but different in some ways that shouldn't have changed, and of course there are some really fun new features too. The gameplay is the well known arcade shooter style we've seen in TF:WfC, but this time it punishes those who favor melee fights by getting blown to pieces almost as easily as we destroy decepticons or autobots for reasons beyond me - propably they wanted to create contrast between some character types.\n\nYou cannot choose which side you want to play as before, but instead the campign is now linear (still you'll get to play equal time on both sides, so don't worry) and changes the side you play on quite often as the story unfolds. The graphics and sounds / voiceovers look and sound just as good as you'd expect it after the first game, and TF:FoC is a steamworks title so you'll find plenty of achievements (on top of ingame collectibles and some hidden extras) to collect. About multiplayer: this is the biggest difference compared to TF:WfC, and not in a good way. CO-OP story is gone. Fall of Cybertron definitly lost a lot replayability because of this if you are not interested in Escalation (CO-OP survival arena, a.k.a. horde mode) or Multiplayer - in which you can create and customize your dream transformer, finally! Pretty much garanteed there are no men out there who wouldn't remember those good ol' childhood let's build one" memories
date: so it's fun - until you find out there aren't many people out there who actually play multiplayer.\n\nThe campign is a blast and despite it's length (6-7 hours) it feels just as long as it's needed to be
recommended: but without co-op the game feels much less than it's prequel. If you loved that
hoursPlayed: you'll love this just as much. Personally I grabbed it when it was on sale for around 13 euros
voteText: I don't regret any of it spent on Fall of Cybertron
helpfulPercent: it's an excellent shooter / beat 'em up with the classic enviroment
votesTotal: but nothing more."

reviewText: This game is a beautiful sequal to Transformers: War for Cybertron. It fixes many of the PC bugs from the last game and the quality is improved. The graphics quality is much better than it is on console. The story is absolutely wonderful and the gameplay styles in the story are everchanging. Like stealth? How about hack and slash? Both of these gameplay styles are included in the third person shooter. The multiplayer is great, not as good as the last game, but still can give you hours upon hours of enjoyment! The escalation mode however is not very good, the limited amount of waves and poor map design makes this gamemode unappealing. The last game had better escalation than this game, but overall it is semi-enoyable. Overall this game is worth buying, it will give you well over 25 hours of enjoyment (depending on how much you play the multiplayer) and I recommend it to anyone who is a fan of third-person shooters! 9/10

reviewText:
Decent game you will complete in a weekend.
Recommended on sale for Transformers G1 fans and only the single player part.
Otherwise there isnt much here outside of that. Do NOT buy the DLC, its MP only.

Pro:
If you like Transformers G1 it adds more and bigger while the game looks decent.
Game mechanics are decent with the transform ability adding a bit of depth.
The story is standard Transformers and everything is mixed up in a good way.
If you liked the first game you will like this one.

Cons:
Had issues getting the game to work.
You can not edit the controls and its clearly a console built game. Very limited settings.
Level design can become a bit samey like the first game because its all on Cybertron.
Ingame Upgrade system looks better than it is. Basically the only thing worthwhile are the perks.
Multiplayer is broken with unbalanced characters, maps, few players and aimboters.
(Didnt play more than 4 matches before I saw at least 2 confirmed aimboters)

reviewText:
PROS: The campaign has good story and gameplay, and also many easter eggs and references to G1, it's clear the developers of the game are true fans of the franchise. Multiplayer is extremely fun, and I may or may not have stayed up until 4am playing it. The freedom to transform wherever you want (also applies to singleplayer), and the ability to customize your own character are probably the two best factors. The game also has a great soundtrack.

CONS: No chat system in multiplayer, which makes communicating with teammates very difficult/pretty much impossible.

Summary: For £15, you can't turn it down. Highly recommended.

reviewText:
Aside from giving War of Cybertron a thumbs down, I think this game deserves some mercy. I'm ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥tting after some Jack Daniel's so stay with me for as long as you can.

So I really liked WFC, it had an amazing campaign much better than the usual ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t games we get. Picking up from rthe last game, robots escaping a dead planet and scavagening any energon they can find. Optimus searching for refuge and Megatron being a general d-bag and not letting them leave. I thought this was a prequel to G1 or Prime but as I've heard it's a game that leads in to the terribly developed, Rise of the Dark Spark, which is a horrendous tie-in with the Bayverse movies. How did that happen? I have no idea.

Campaign was good, the storyline wasnt really much for me to remember as the first game was but the change in enviroment was great. One thing I absolutely loved was Metroplex, how often do we get to see that guy? How they managed to work him into the storyline was awesome. I would have liked to see some more characters though. Yes, playing as Optimus and Megatron is the primary focus but the side characters are just as important.

I did not like how there was no choice in character for mission nor was there any co-op campaign. There seemed to be more fun with two other characters and also how they can help (aside from their meager dps). Focusing on one character seems to make it not only a little more challenging but almost personal even though we did have side conversation all along. As for co-op I was really disappointed. I had a lot of fun in co-op back in WFC so to see I can't enjoy the campaign with a friend really cuts back on a lot.

Now High Moon did ♥♥♥♥ up. Again.

I will give them props for at least being respectful enough for giving us DLC but they failed to even patch the game. I played WFC and FOC on Xbox when both released and did not run into as many problems as I did on this platform. I have run into several instances where I was freefalling out the map, stuck in the floor, had to navigate around invisible walls, and other game breaking glitches. I had to reset my game numerous times or wait for 10 minutes just to continue playing. Not only that but some game interactions don't even work, like when Megatron is in Soundwave's lab.

I will stress this again like I did in my WFC review, don't play multiplayer. Don't play in a public game. The multiplayer community is still around but there are players using infinite shield, FPS unlocker, rapidfire, and other unfair hacks to ruin the game. And just like in the last game, High Moon will do nothing about it. This game was dropped as soon as it was released much like it's last game which is still very disappointing.

Recommended for campaign use only.

reviewText: The campaign is just as good as War for Cybertron's campaign (maybe a little more difficult) but unfortunately the multiplayer is much much worse than War for Cybertrons multiplayer. reviewText: When I first purchased this game I was stoked! I finally got the game on sale. I remember War for Cybertron and recalled how that game was definitely NOT worth $60. When Fall of Cybertron went on sale I purchased a copy and jumped right in. Immediately I realized how much it resembled War for Cybertron. It is almost identical. Some things were improved and to a great extent. I LOVE the variety in multiplayer mode and it gives me hope that one day Transformers will have a place in the mass online gaming community, but I can't believe how many issues there are. Firstly, you cannot aim directly above you, which gives the scientist class an unfair advantage since they can hover directly over you. Nextly, invisible walls. Seriously, you glitch the hell out on these things, and there are a TON of them. I've died countless times because I've gotten stuck on what seemed to be nothing. After that there is the matter of team member collisions. When you so much as touch your team members you go FLYING off in some random direction or get stuck: especially if transforming around them. The only thing worse than that is you can't even play multiplayer because there are such few people who play the game. And even if you do get in a match you won't be able to play a whole match without Host Migration" happening and ruining the whole match (causing you to forfeit all your EXP). There are many more problems in this game... like HACKERS. There are a ton of cheaters in this game and it makes multiplayer pointless. Overall there are just too many problems. If you can get a solid match in with honest players it can be very fulfilling. Fall of Cybertron is still NOT worth $60
date: considering TF2 is free to play and has far fewer problems in my opinion.\n\nSee my screenshots."

reviewText:
Review on game:
Game itself is good. I loved War for Cybertron, waited a few years to play Fall of Cybertron, and once i started playing, feel right back into the groove of how the game plays. Story continuation is good, and i love the addition of the dinobots and insecticons. Ending was a little weak 8/10.

Review on Multiplayer:
Multiplayer is dead for the most part. You might find a small group on whenever steam does a decent sale on this game, but past that, no one plays the multiplayer anymore.

Review on DLC:
DLC is mostly for multiplayer, and the weapons arent that great. You will find better weapons in the game. I wouldnt advice buying any of it unless its bundled for a decent price, and even then I still wouldnt recommend it as its just a waste of space.

All in all, I would only recommend this game for people who only care about the campaign portion. I wouldnt pay full price for this game. Steam/Activision need to do a serious price drop on this game, as well as Rise of the Dark Spark, for the same reason due to the multiplayer in both games being dead, which makes the DLC useless.

reviewText: One of the best Transformers games for today, Fall Of Cybertron is a sequel to War For Cybertron which shows the last days of war between Autobots led by Optimus Prime and Decepticons led by Megatron. The campaing is filled with pure adrenaline action and epic fights. You will be able to play as good and bad guys during whole campaing which is outstanding. You can collect currency to upgrade your guns or buy new ones as well as some perks which give you little bonuses during gameplay. The fights are unique and very well improved from predecessor. Transforming into vehicle is very rewarding and fun. Especially playing as Grimlock who can transform into T-Rex. Game also includes coop survival mode Escalation up to 3 players to fight off many waves of enemies and finally multiplayer is all fun. But because game is a bit old you won't see many people online. In summary it's a great game as previous but have some problems of it's own. PC port isn't good enough and devellopers dropped coop campaing which is really bad. In times textures won't load up so you have to restart checkpoint, and because of that game can't get big score. Outstanding performance, great soundtrack, great voice acting, nice graphics. Take it if you are a fan, and if not still give it a try. 8/10.

reviewText:
This is probably an amazing game, because War For Cybertron certainly was.

However,
The servers for both Escalation and Multiplayer are down, so it is impossible to play with friends. If you're just in it for the campaign, go ahead. I should warn you though, the campaign is extremely laggy. I had a bit of chop here and there with WFC, but my computer freezes every 30 seconds with FOC. I have by no means a high end PC, but it should be able to run this game on the lowest graphical settings. Unfortunately, it Doesn't.

Again, if the campaign is all you need, and you have a powerful computer, then by all means, buy this game. Otherwise, stay away.

reviewText: First off, let me start out saying that I am a die-hard transformers fan. I've loved the series for a while now and I loved this game's prequal, War for Cybertron. With that in mind I have to say I was very disappointed with this game. The campaign is very short while being still enjoyable (the best part of the game). It follows an interesting plot and rather engaging gameplay. The main problem I have with it is one, it's way too short. You can easily beat this game in about 5-6 hours. 7 max. Two, it's too gimmicky for its own good. The gunplay in it the game is rather nice but it feels like you never do it too often. Overall, I'd give the campaign a 6/10. The length really ruins it for me. Now let's move on the gosh-awful Multiplayer. Now, I want to reference War for Cybertron again and say that the Multiplayer in that game was incredible. Insanely fun, never really got boring, and some interesting maps. The only real problem was that it needed polish in some areas. In this game, however, they take out all those things that made War's so much fun. Most of the maps are very uninteresting with only two being really enjoyable. Another big problem is balancing, every class in the game, and I mean EVERY class has something that can be considered overpowered. It's no longer skill that wins games, it's who has the highest level, which is one of the biggest problems to me. The Multiplayer itself can also get very boring, some of the maps are way too big for the game types the game offers. Oh, and did I forget to mention there are only 4 game modes in this game with 2 of them being practically the same? There are also tons of hackers on the game.Now there is one last mode to talk about and that is Escalation. It's your standard Zombies" or "Survival mode". It's a nice little take away and can be fun with friends but there are only 4 maps and only 15 waves which is disappointing.  Now
date: I'll recap all the things I said and
hoursPlayed:
things I think are positive or negative. Please consider that this is just my own opinion so it may greatly differ form yours. Thank you.

Campaign:6/10
+Fantastic voice acting
+Good gunplay (When it's used)
+Creative level design
+Great graphics (At max settings)
-Way too short
-Too many boring gimmicks
-Not a very good sense of being a in a war

Multiplayer:3/10
-Very unbalanced
-Full of hackers/cheaters
-Uninteresting maps
-Only four game modes
+Great graphics (At max settings again)
+More customization

Escalation:5/10
-Limited waves
-Lacks charm
-Only four maps
+Fun distraction
+Good sense of teamwork

My final verdict:4/10
This game could've been so much but falls so short in many areas. Either save your money (Espcially considering that this game is 60$) or

reviewText:
Take everything that made War for Cybertron good, and water it down to eliminate the skill involved.

Mercenary Technologies took a good platform and ruined it with poor balance choices while attempting to appeal to a broader (Call of Duty) audience. Getting kills in multiplayer is more a factor of luck than actual skill.

If you want to play a game that was made by Transformers fans, check out Transformers Devastation or Transformers War for Cybertron. This is just Bandai cashing in.

reviewText:
Fans of the Transformers series I am sorry to disappoint you, but I must insist that this is NOT the best Transformers game on the market, nor is it even a good one.

High my name is EXtraDonut, I am a scholar at UTI and I graduated twice at IBS, studying media as a whole. This year I held a TedX talk over at Monroe University in Chicahuaga California about the history of sci-fi over the last 100 years. I covered everything from the rise of pulp novels bringing about astonishing tales of virtue and valor as astronauts fought their way across the stars battling giant space squids and evil lamprey eels of death, to the modern epics of CGI mayhem brought to us in glorious HD-3D IMAX. One particular franchise I covered, was Transformers. You see, Transformerds has a colored history. It started in the 1940's as a way to sell toys to kids in a way that would also bolster interest in the American's upcoming space ventures, and continued on to become a staple of science fiction.

My issue with this game is based on its inherent disregard for the canon set by Michael Bay, which Hasbro(which I may remind you is the leading authority on Transformers since the 1940's pulp era) said in a public statement that the movie trilogy is a firm part of the Transformers canon. Now in the game Transformers Fall of Cybertron, the first thing I pointed out to my wife(god bless that ♥♥♥♥♥ Suzanne) is that Optimus Prime no longer looks like a chromed up god, but rather like the box covered idiot look from the 1940's, something that has clearly not aged well at all. Oh well, I considered it an artistic difference and moved on, but this occurs for ALL of the characters in the game. Listen up folks, if you're creating an IP and you set a canon up for people to adhere to, do not hire incompetent IDIOTS who will trash on that canon completely like the folks over at High Moon did. Secondly(and this is my biggest concern), Megatron dies on the third chapter. That's dumb, Megatron is crazy powerful and if you're going to kill him off, do it during an omnicron storyline so he can come back as Galvatron you IDIOTS. What's the point of Megatron dying for his people to the traitorous Optimus Prime(the Judas of this story) if he does not get revived by what is the god figure of this franchise? The whole mythology behind Transformers is Catholic, Mr. Bay understood this perfectly when he made his movies. High Moon Studios is a group of anti-religious nuts enforcing their Atheist ways on us god loving gamers.

I cannot, I WILL NOT endorse this franchise ever again, not to my church gaming group, not to ANYBODY... PERIOD.

reviewText: A fun game any fan of transformers should like.

The single player is pretty awesome, but after beating it ten thousand times and unlocking all the weapons it gets a bit boring. It would help if it had co-op, but oh well.

Now, the multiplayer is GREAT, and is my favorite part of the game. It can be a bit hard at first, when u havent unlocked anything or have turned prime, but it adds to the challenge. And the character creation might even be my favorite part of the multiplayer, because of trying to create G1 characters and just seeing all of the cool combos u can make is AWESOME. But I wish that they still had your enemies drop their weapons when they die, like in WfC.

Escalation is also boss, but i really wish that u could still pick any character instead of just four,but i see y they did that. Other than that, its a great game mode. i also wish that they still had unlimited levels, but i guess that it does help and make it a bit easier since there are 15 lvls.

Overall, this game is AWESOME, and is probably my favorite game alongside its previous game, War for Cybertron. I really hope they make a third, but adding the good things from WfC that they left out in FoC. if they did that in a third game, that would probably be the best game ever.

this is a fun sequel to transformers: war for cybertron. The campaign mode is decently fun. you can earn credits to buy weapons and equip any weapon to any character. Sadly there are only twelve levels, but they make up for that by putting things in certain levels to find such as audio logs ( sound tracks of characters explaining the events, and such), and blueprints (collect these to unlock weapons and perks). The multiplayer mode is decent as far as gameplay. The gameplay is the same as the campaign\ngameplay.  The characters are pretty customizable except for the fact that only certain character loadouts can use certain weapons, vehicle modes, and perks. Some of the multiplayer maps are big and some are rather small. The multiplayer modes are mostly PVP oriented, but there is one mode where you can battle waves of enemies with other players. Most of the maps in this mode are actually very large.

i picked up this and WFC in the sale and i like these games, the story is great, the references are many and the roit cannon (megatron's gun for this game) certainly gives the impression that what you're shooting at won't enjoy it. unfortunatly one critisicm i have is that megatron seemed a little frail. that might be because i'm bad but he just seemed to die a lot for me. maybe soundwave rebuilt him out of yellow plastic...

another criticism is that in wfc you could pick up any two different guns (and a detachable turret gun, also ommited from this) but in this it orders guns into light and heavy weapons and you can only have one of each.  it more than makes up for it with sheer weapon variety. there's a machine gun light weapon but if you want that slot for something else then there's a chaingun heavy wep. in heavy there's acid cannons, missile launchers, the aforementioned chaingun and even the 'cyber corrupt@r' that can turn the various mook bots and cons over to your side. and the best thing is that all these weapons can be upgraded with crate money stuff.

also i heard that glass gass was unlocked when i won the campaign and i think i can remember what that does.

player characters wise there is a fair amount. prime and megs of course and the obligitory bumblebee, jazz and cliffjumper, starscream, the combaticons (and bruticus), soundwave and his cassets, jetfire, metroplex's guns and grimlock
also one more character (with no noteriety) but describing him will spoil the suprise... that happons to him.

so all in all in singleplayer a good game that is fun.

Let me get something out up front, I am a massive Transformers fan; I've seen every TV show, I've read every book and I have e-copies of every comic (which admittidly I never made it too far into). On top of all that I tend to be extremely critical. My criteria may be harsh but Fall of Cybertron is excellent. The game is a refreshing twist on the shooter genre as a whole, with the ability to switch weapon arms to shoot around cover, and the flawlessly integrated transformation mechanics. Vehicle alt-modes are surprisingly varied and, unlike most Transformer (and almost all other mech/robotic) games break from the mold of tanks, scouts and planes with only slightly different textures to distinguish them. I will say however that this is slightly damaged in the multiplayer due to an unfortunate, but probably unavoidable class system. Fortunately the game has an excellent character creation system that allows you to at least look unique. In terms of the campaign the game has been fantastic. The references and glimpses of past series and stories are plentiful, but have been worked in in such a ways that players new to the universe could have an hugely enjoyable experience without understanding them one bit. Then we get to perhaps my biggest praise: the characters. The characters in Fall of Cybertron are outstanding, the voice acting is fantastic and creates personas for essential characters and grunt soldiers a like. This is most true in the case of the Autobots; I genuinely felt a tinge of regret in the Decepticon missions killing Autobot soldiers. Their cheerful but nervous banter and yelled conversations made them seem like actual beings, I remember playing as Megatron and hearing one Autobot yell out He can fly now?!?! That is not ok
date: THAT IS NOT OK!!!" as he retreated

Transformers: Fall of Cybertron

Almost every second I spent with Transformers: Fall of Cybertron, my inner 8-year old child was jumping up and down with uncontained glee. Here I am playing a videogame controling none other than Optimus Prime, and it's every bit as cool as I always dreamt it would be. I'm stomping around Cybertron, blasting Decepticons, turning into a truck and I feel in every way that the experince could not have made me 'feel' more like my childhood hero without implanting my conciousness into his robotic brain.

Honestly if it sounds like I'm gushing, it's because I am. As a kid I discovered Transformers at about the perfect time and the franchise resonated with me in a big way.  As such, Transformers: Fall of Cybertron hit all the right notes and is exactly the sort of power fantasy my inner child has craved since Christmas of 1993, when a 5-year-old me unwrapped the coolest toy I would ever own, hands shaking from excitement: my very own Optimus Prime...

Mechanically I found Fall of Cybertron was kept engaging throughout by an ever-changing roster of playable characters. Each level presents you with at least one new character from the Transformers universe, each  feeling unique with their own combat mechanics and transformation mode. This ever changing set of toys to play with keeps the game fresh and interesting throughout and is Fall of Cybertron's most remarkable feature.

Outside of this however, Fall of Cybertron gets a little less easy to enthuse over. Graphically the game is average, the enemy variety feels pretty lacking and the plot is exactly what you would expect from an 80s cartoon franchise designed to sell transforming robot toys: uninspired, kind of silly and rammed chock full of fan service. It must also be said that what I tried of the multiplayer mode I found a little dull, which was a shame, partially due to how few people I could find playing. I dare to say if you took away the Transformers licence from Fall of Cybertron you would simply be left with a competent but unremarkable 3rd person shooter I would be hard pressed to recommend to anyone.

But heres the important thing... It does have the Transformers licence. It's got it in truck loads, and it is the excellent - nay impeccible - implimentation of this licence that carries Fall of Cybertron from the pits of  mediocrity and makes it such a solidly enjoyable game.

Would I recommend? Yes, if the thought of getting to be a Transformer sounds remotely exciting to you, then Transformers: Fall of Cybertron will not disappoint.

Wonderful tribute to both the TV series and the comic books, with lot's of obscure references for long time fans to spot.
Some beautiful  graphics, resulting in very distinguishable charcter models  & the best depiction of Cyberton yet.
Good variety in both area design and gameplay playstyles (Stealth, acrobatics, flight etc)
Exceptionally good musical score that shifts according to the action or lack of.
Complete lack of any Michael Bay's influences.

Negatives:
Slightly finnicky wireless controller support (menu's still require the mouse)
Occasional crashes

The story was short yet fun.

I really, really like this game. The quality of the campaign has benefitted immensely from the removal of co-op like the last game had, which at first was a controversial decision by the devs but turned out to be the best possible choice. I had an absolute blast playing as racecars, tanks, helicopters, jets, giant bots, dinosaurs, and even grunts as I sneaked around with cloaking devices, grappled through aerial fortresses, crossed swords with decepticons, stepped on autobots, incinerated leapers, dogfought (is that a word?) with enemy planes, *SPOILERS*ate shockwave,*END SPOILERS* I could go on. For a long time. Needless to say the campaign was awesome and I will be playing it through several times again. The multiplayer portion of the game does not fare so well; I failed to see any improvement in the competitive or cooperative survival modes, and at any time you try to play you will either a) only find hackers or b) not find anyone at all. It's a shame HMS and Activision wont get their act together on support, I'd boycott them but unfortunately I have too much fun on their games to bother. There I said it, I'm a horrible PC gamer...  but I'm a great TF fan. Do your self a favor, buy this game and enjoy what you can.\n\nTill all are one...""

Review:
This is an excellent game for all Transformers fans out there! I would recommend this game very much even to non-transformers fans, you guys I gonna love it. This game has a very fun and cool campaign with a very interesting and unexpecting storyline. The only thing different from Transformers WFC is that it has no Co-Op mode but, they improve the character customization system for multiplayer which is AWSOME! You customize your character from head to leg. Multiplayer was really fun and competitive they did a very great job improving the game.

Suggestions:
There are some improvements that can be made to make the game (or future versions of it) even more awsome. Firstly I like the color system in Transformers WFC where you can pick the colors as well as the different tones of it I wish the color system can be brought back with even more colors. Secondly,  since character customization is for us customize a Transformers to make it our very own, I was hoping that we can Decepticon colors and Autobots colors for both factions because some colors like White and Black are used mostly in both Autobots and Decepticons. I was also hoping that we can customize any Transformers for any class so that we can have for example Ratchet as the Scientist class, Scout class, Leader class or Titan class as well as weapons being available for all classes. Thirdly, I still love how Transformers WFC where we get to customize both the Autobot and the Decepticon for every slot (Scout 1, Scout 2, Scout 3) because in Transformers FOC, we can only customize the character and then choose an Autobot color and a Decepticon color instead of customizing one unique Autobot and one Unique Decepticon. I hope you can take my suggestions for consideration to make the game better. I know you guys put a lot of effort into this game just that some very good stuffs were remove.

Others:
I heard that Transformers ROTDS was quite a failure because of the fact that you guys removed multiplayer from the game. The storyline was not very well done because of merging 2 different Transformers universe together. I was hoping that you guys can release a DLC for Transformers ROTDS that removes all the earth missions and replace it with new cybertron missions and show how the dark spark was destroyed. I understand the cybertron missions take place between WFC and FOC I was hoping that you can link the 3 together as well as bringing back multiplayer and character customization. By removing the earth missions, I hope a a new game base on the movie Transformers AOE can be made seperately from Transformers ROTDS. I think people would pay and extra sum of money for the DLC just to get a better game. I hope you guys can consider it. Thank you for your precious time reading this. :D
