This game is essentially one step forward and three steps back from the first. The co-op is gone, the levels are much more linear, and the Transformation gimmick is much less useful here.

There is quite a variety of play styles beyond the standard over-the-shoulder shooter levels, such as stealth sections, rooftop sniping, flying through giant chasms, and giant-robot-dinosaur beat-em-ups, but they all only happen once or twice before being shoved away more more boring levels. There are many good ideas that only happen once and are never touched on again and they are unsatisfyingly short and easy due to their one-off nature. Grimlock himself is probably the biggest disappointment of all since you only play as him for one level at the very end.

The multiplayer sucks as well since it has that dreadful Call of Duty time sink xp system. Basically, you start with a few guns, and as you spend more time playing, you unlock more, but it takes so damn long to unlock anything and you're at the mercy of players who have far more options than you because they have more weapon because you can't play this game for 8 hours a day. Also the Dinobots are DLC, which is a real slap in the face since they were practically the most hyped part of the game. Thankfully, you shouldn't have to worry about any of these problems because the online is dead and there's no local multiplayer or co-op.

This game is only for hardcore transformers fans who like the brand more than they do fun, so if you're okay with a boring game with a nonsensical plot with ugly levels and lame multiplayer just because it says Transformers on it, then you already own this. Everyone else should avoid.

As a Transfan myself, I had high expectations from this game, when it's trailer came out. But nothing could prepare me for this sequel to Transformers: War For Cybertron. The overall story of these two games gives us a new look on the history of the war for Cybertron before they came to Earth. The graphic quality is good, the controls feel nice and smooth, and it is not as bad on the health bar as it was for War For Cybertron. The multiplayer part of this game is okay, but could be worked on, for PS3 version. The plot runs smoothly and I liked how they presented the first playable part of the game. I highly recommend this game to any Transfan or someone new to the series to play it, but you should play War For Cybertron first even though it can induce a rage quite here and there, it will help in the long run, trust me.

This game is pretty good in all, gameplay, plot, design, art... be sure that you will enjoy it.\nThe problem appears if you have play War of Cybertron first because this game is his continuation but it's worse in everything. Spectacular game. Truly. And I only have played through the campaign. Truly takes me back to the cartoons. If you want action non stop with really diverse settings, pretty awesome characters, and some nifty jokes, this is the game for you. I picked it up for 5 bucks and it has been in the top of my list of best 5 dollar things I've bought! Crazy good, buy it yo!

First of all I'd like to mention that I'm honestly surprised about what is left out of this compared to the Xbox 360 version. For some reason the multiplayer customisation only has half of the colours now and for some reason the game doesn't have the CGI trailer to view anymore.

There's numerous unlocking glitches such as the weapons you are supposed to get after finishing the campaign not appearing as well as many achievments not popping up. These however are not terribly influential on how good the game is, I just feel that these issues need to be addressed.

The campaign is fantastic, really giving off a feel of the Transformers world with memorable characters and great voice acting. It was a little confusing how much they deviate from the G1 continuity as War For Cybetron made me think they were prequels to the cartoon.

Not much is happening on the multiplayer now but it has been out for a good few years now so a drop in full sessions is to be expected.

If you get this game for anything, get it for the campaign. If you're a Transformers fan you shouldn't be disappointed.

The good:  You get to play both sides of the story.  Each side offers up a slightly different experience that doesn't feel repetative.  You can choose from a few Transformers from each side to play their campaign.  Graphically, the game looks quite nice.  Peter Cullen as Optimus Prime!

Room for improvement:  The camera sucks!  It's too close in vehicle and robot modes.  Some distance would be greatly appreciated.  Personally, I think first person would be a better implementation.  I would like to see more voice actors to fill out the characters.  Te talent for those who aren't officially voiced by the people who did them in a series is still good but they could have gone the extra mile with this.
i rikey

Ok so I've wanted this game for a while, but didn't want to pay much as I fully expected to be very disappointed. As a fan of the cartoons from back in the day, and a hater of the new films (they ruined every character design, and I mean EVERY) I expected this to be more new style than old.

Yet somehow those who made this game managed to 'improve' the designs, yet keeping to each characters true design and stylings. This game is a prequel to what most people know (I've only 'watched' the first film so they may have told you more than I believe). So seeing the autobots in the homeworld states is kind of cool.

As for the game itself I didn't expect such a fairly solid shooting mechanic, instead of sticking to a corner to and it peering around, you change your gun arm to give better viewing while remaining well covered. The weapons are varied and very cool. There are upgrades for both robot and vehicle form. And so far all the major names appear to be making appearences.

I am not all that far, only in chapter four of thirteen. But so far there has been hold and fight sections, stealth sections (optional), side sections to search for the blueprints / logs if you want to do them. All from a game I fully expected to play half hour and then never play again.

So do I recommend this game, yes, yes I do very much.

G1 Transformers re-imagined origin story. What's not to love? This game rocks. Played it on Xbox 360, it was awesome. Playing it on my rig at full 1080p maxed out? Incredible. The amount of detail i missed out on is jaw dropping.

THIS is the defining TF game. WfC was great, but this took it to a whole new level.

One can only imagine the merging of this series with the crappy Bayformers movie series in the next installment 'Rise of the Dark Spark' will probably ensure that this title remains the absolute greatest version for a long time to come.

One thing to note, make sure you have anti-aliasing disabled or set to be handled by the application as default. Otherwise you'll think the game is broken when you start the game and everything looks like an acid trip and you can see objects you shouldn't be able to see, and background layers come through while foreground layers dissapear.

this is a fun sequel to transformers: war for cybertron. The campaign mode is decently fun. you can earn credits to buy weapons and equip any weapon to any character. Sadly there are only twelve levels, but they make up for that by putting things in certain levels to find such as audio logs ( sound tracks of characters explaining the events, and such), and blueprints (collect these to unlock weapons and perks). The multiplayer mode is decent as far as gameplay. The gameplay is the same as the campaign\ngameplay.  The characters are pretty customizable except for the fact that only certain character loadouts can use certain weapons, vehicle modes, and perks. Some of the multiplayer maps are big and some are rather small. The multiplayer modes are mostly PVP oriented, but there is one mode where you can battle waves of enemies with other players. Most of the maps in this mode are actually very large.

if u think this game is for children u need to WAKE UP time to try it out and see how it's really like (wiht awesome robot changes) :3

The single player is pretty awesome, but after beating it ten thousand times and unlocking all the weapons it gets a bit boring. It would help if it had co-op, but oh well.

Now, the multiplayer is GREAT, and is my favorite part of the game. It can be a bit hard at first, when u havent unlocked anything or have turned prime, but it adds to the challenge. And the character creation might even be my favorite part of the multiplayer, because of trying to create G1 characters and just seeing all of the cool combos u can make is AWESOME. But I wish that they still had your enemies drop their weapons when they die, like in WfC.

Escalation is also boss, but i really wish that u could still pick any character instead of just four,but i see y they did that. Other than that, its a great game mode. i also wish that they still had unlimited levels, but i guess that it does help and make it a bit easier since there are 15 lvls.

Overall, this game is AWESOME, and is probably my favorite game alongside its previous game, War for Cybertron. I really hope they make a third, but adding the good things from WfC that they left out in FoC. if they did that in a third game, that would probably be the best game ever.

You don't play as a generic mercenary (or the like) so it already has a leg up on the competition.  You get to play as both the Autobots and the Decepticons and it reinforces the fact that the Decepticons are simply better.

Playtime: 9h
8/10
NOT to be missed by any Transformers fan, moreso for veterans of War for Cybertron!

In my opinion this is one of the best transformers games out there. Games like war, fall and the new one, transformers devastation, have done something new to keep their games fresh. But ignore rise of the dark spark, that game is a cash in, that trys to rip off what made this game so great. But lets talk about this game. Sadly i think this game is the last, we will see high moon make a transformers game, since the games ending actually ties into the g1 story.  But besides that if you don't know already, transformers fall of cybertron is the game after the game war for cybertron. Just to let you know so you can buy war for cybertron first, and then this game. When you start fall of cybertron, play the campaign. The campaign is great, and besides. What game has metroplex in it!! A freaking g1 city former making its entrance in modern games. If you played war you can tell the game has changed. I believe double jumping is the thing in the past. But i can push that away. Another weird thing is that optimus changed him mold or body, but its never explained. But you can forget that fact.  I am not going to spoil the story in sake of the review, but you probably know that metroplex is going to be in it, from all the hyped trailers that came out. Its good that transformers campaigns are great since this is how you are probably going to remember them. Plus i haven't played multiplayer on pc but i have on the 360. And lets face it, the game is becoming old and will proabably have a bunch of cheaters in it. So i don't recommend playing multiplayer at all on pc. But you should try escalation. Its good but why is it capped at level 15? In war you can go up to unlimited rounds but who cares i guess. I mostly played it for the campaign and the fan service is there. I am still playing this in 2016 and i still enjoy it, so is that saying something. Well i am a transformers fan, but i think that you should try it out anyway.

I had this game on the PS3 and remember playing it for hours on end along side other great games. This game is amazing for any Transformer fan, which you're probably hearing a lot about from other reviews, and for a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ good reason.

Sad thing about this game is as of today, the Multiplayer is dead, from my 7 hours of playing as I write this I have only had one full match of Escalation--the games horde mode. But enough just chatting about the game, lets list the Pros and Cons

Pros:
- Great level variety
- Diverse enemies, engaging combat
- Weapon upgrade system through Teletran-1
- Replay value is great
- Play as multiple characters in Campaign and in Multiplayer

Multiplayer Pros:
- Create your own Autobot or Decepticon
- Good progression system
- DLC is actually worth purchasing, and is not pay to win by any means
- Decent amount of modes

Cons:
- No Co-op campaign (not a major con, but if you liked it WFC then you may miss having it like me)
- There are some bugs/glitches (For me was Eye of the Storm had level loading problems, wait for a few minutes near Jazz for it to fix.)

Multiplayer Cons:
- Multiplayer is overall dead
- Progression to Max level Prime is time consuming
- Escalation can become bland quickly, dispite the many different maps

In conclusion, great game and still holds up to this day. So glad my nostalgia for this is not just me being an idiot :P

reviewText: Now this is how you make a quality game

Fall of Cybertron is a solid third-person shooter with some interesting transforming mechanics. While I'm not so keen on the singleplayer, the multiplayer is pretty cool. Most people say that the multiplayer is dead. Whoo-hoo-hoo, look who knows so much. It just so happens that your multiplayer here is only MOSTLY dead. There's a big difference between mostly dead and all dead. Mostly dead is slightly alive. Aside from that, I'm not really so sure it's worth 50 bucks.\nIf it's massively on sale, I would definitely pick it up. If not, I'd read more reviews and think carefully.

Really good single player. Multiplayer is sort of non-existant, but fun if you can actually get a game going. I'd suggest buying on sale, and hopefully having a friend to play the games horde mode. An Excellent Game in Disguise
Transformers: Fall of Cybertron is one of the best games I've ever played, and I'm not being hyperbolic. High Moon Studios has managed to craft an engaging, emotional and entertaining game centered around giant transforming robots, which really shouldn't be hard. As it stands, Fall of Cybertron is definitely the best Transformers game ever made, and is also one of the best shooters out there, period.

Fall of Cybertron is visually astonishing. The environments are huge and varied, with a large amount of color variation and imaginative design. Characters have incredibly amounts of detail: gears whirr, guns pulse with ammunition, and panels shift on character models, even when they're idle. When they move, joints shift and pump, and guns fire a variety of bright and gleaming projectiles. The wonderfully unique enemies spark and blaze as they come apart, and transformation sequences showcase enormous amounts of detail that leaves you stunned when the animation ends.

The music is fantastic, showcasing some satisfying electirc guitar beats for the action-packed moments, alongside some excellent synth tracks and atmospheric pieces for when things quiet down. All of the voice work is on par with the best triple-A RPGs, and some of the original voice cast was recruited for the game (Peter Cullen as Optimus Prime is godlike).

The story goes in some truly unexpected directions and gets surprisingly heavy at times. The early missions wouldn’t be out-of-place in the grittiest “war-is-hell” game/movie/book/documentary, and the game isn’t afraid to get realistic with the consequences of a civil war between transforming robots on a cybernetic planet. The final few missions don’t quite live up to the rest of the game’s narrative excellence, but that’s only due to how sudden the ending feels and the ambiguity regarding the fate of the Dinobots.

The game’s combat is fantastic. Using the shift key to dodge and sprint took a while to get used to, but it feels natural after a few levels. Guns are satisfying and varied, with a Transformers twist on familiar staples in the genre. While the upgrade system starts of dull (you’re going to get really sick of increasing your movement speed while scoped), the late-tier upgrades are phenomenally unique, powerful, and fun to get. I could have done with a few more levels of upgrades considering that each gun only gets between two to four, but it’s still exciting to level them up.

Finding the hidden blueprints to make new guns won’t be a problem unless you never explore, but there was one exception: a bug during Cliffjumper’s mission prevented the final blueprint from spawning, and I had to replay that level a few times to get it to work.

Enemies are extremely aggressive and intelligent. Basic soldiers hide behind cover, flush you out with grenades, and move if you start to advance, but they’re just the tip of the iceberg.  Shotgun Decepticons and Autobots rush you at incredible speed, only taking cover if you’re particularly far away, and dive backwards into cover if you try to close the gap. Snipers rapidly switch between vantage points, and that’s still not all of them. The enemies take the already interesting arsenal and make you use to it its full capability on anything except the easiest difficulty.

In an example of something I really wish wasn’t astonishing but is due to the poor pedigree of previous Transformers games (Excluding War for Cybertron), the game has, finally, managed to capture the essence of Transformers in a way that makes it unlike a standard third-person shooter: transformation is now a vital part of combat. As enemies reposition themselves, Optimus Prime could dance around, avoiding their fire as he waits for them to expose themselves, or he could transform and ram into them to finish the job.

Using the mouse to move around feels strange at first, but after getting in aerial dogfights that felt like they were straight out of a flight combat game or kiting enemies while I peppered them with vehicular rockets, I wouldn’t have it any other way. The game’s smooth integration of each interlocking system allows for such incredible feats as being able to scream forward at top speed as Jazz, jump, transform in midair, grapple onto a ledge, and lock onto and snipe an enemy in the span of less than six seconds.

On that note, the game also distinguishes itself with the huge amount of variety. Every single level, and sometimes multiple times within the same level, you switch to a new character with a whole new set of abilities. This transition, with only three exceptions in the cases of Starscream, Soundwave, and  Bumblebee  always feels natural, and only in those exceptions does it feel like you didn’t spend enough time with certain characters. New enemy types are introduced as you play new characters, but even with regards to enemies you’ve fought before, your character’s new stature, vehicle form, special ability and possible armament means you need to change how you fight them. For example,  Insecticons  are huge threats to Jazz even in small numbers, but Grimlock can literally just walk on them. It's a bit of a shame that character's don't have unique melee attacks, though.

Fall of Cybertron is one of the best action games I’ve ever played, and one of my favorite games ever, period. It combines excellent storytelling, audio, visuals, combat and other underlying systems to craft an experience unlike any other I’ve ever played.

Now if only Activision would finally listen to my THREE WEEKS of trying to get technical support and let me play the ♥♥♥♥ing multiplayer.

Pros Excellent visuals, whether it's character models or environment design
Fantastic voice acting and music
Engaging, varied combat
Upgrade system is great fun
Huge number of playable characters that are each fun and used well
Interesting characters and surprisingly emotional story
Vehicle form is actually really useful and importantCons Ending is kind of sudden and the last few story missions try to wrap up things a little too quickly
Starscream, Soundwave and Bumblebee aren't playable for as long as I'd like
They didn't quite capture Grimlock's style of speech as well as I'd like, and one of the Dinobots is killed off with little ceremony

Great follow up to the previous entry and generally a great game.  For some reason seemed to fly under the radar, but a must play for any fan of Transformers.

If you are a Transformers fan or even had a passing interest in them as a kid, you owe it to yourself to play this game.  High Moon deserves proper support from the gaming community for treating the subject material of so many of our childhoods with proper respect (unlike certain movies I could name).  If you are kind of indifferent about the franchise it is still a very solid 3rd person action game worthy of your time and money.

First of all I'd like to mention that I'm honestly surprised about what is left out of this compared to the Xbox 360 version. For some reason the multiplayer customisation only has half of the colours now and for some reason the game doesn't have the CGI trailer to view anymore.

There's numerous unlocking glitches such as the weapons you are supposed to get after finishing the campaign not appearing as well as many achievments not popping up. These however are not terribly influential on how good the game is, I just feel that these issues need to be addressed.

The campaign is fantastic, really giving off a feel of the Transformers world with memorable characters and great voice acting. It was a little confusing how much they deviate from the G1 continuity as War For Cybetron made me think they were prequels to the cartoon.

Not much is happening on the multiplayer now but it has been out for a good few years now so a drop in full sessions is to be expected.

If you get this game for anything, get it for the campaign. If you're a Transformers fan you shouldn't be disappointed.
